Vitamins

05 Aug 2013

I am not good at reading LOOONG articles. I just want to make them short. So, I can tell what is good and what is not good.

IU = international units

Vitamin A

    Retinol, Retinal, and Retinoc acid
  • Good for
    • Vision
    May lower prostate cancer risk
    Keeps tissues and skin healthy
    Important to Bone growth
    May lower lung cancer risk
    Antioxidants
    May protect against cataracts
  • Side effects
    • Too much vitamin A (but not beta carotene) can be harmful to bones
  • Food
    • Sources of retinoids:
    beef, liver, eggs, shrimp, fish, fortified milk, cheddar cheese, Swiss cheese
    Sources of beta carotene:
    sweet potatoes, carrots, pumkins, squash, spinach, mangoes, turnip greens
  • Limit per day
    • 3,000 mcg (about 10,000 IU)
  • Recommended amount (daily)
    • Men: 900 mcg (3,000 IU)
    Women: 700 mcg (2,333 IU)

Vitamin B1

    Thiamin
  • Good for
    • Helps convert food into energy
    Needed for healthy skin, hair, muscles, and brain
  • Side effects
    • ???
  • Food
    • soy milk, watermelons, acorn squash
    Pork chops, ham
  • Limit per day
    • Not Known
  • Recommended amount (daily)
    • Men: 1.2 mg
    Women: 1.1 mg

Vitamin B2

    Riboflavin
  • Good for
    • Helps convert food into energy
    Needed for healthy skin, hair, blood, and brain
  • Side effects
    • Not Known
  • Food
    • whole and enriched grains and cereals
    Milk, yogurt, cheese, liver.
  • Limit per day
    • Not Known
  • Recommended amount (daily)
    • Men: 1.3 mg
    Women: 1.1 mg
